The Financial Secretary knows as well as we do on this side that this is an unfair tax which is being imposed by the Clause. When I saw the other day that the total tax relief given on employees' contributions under the National Insurance Scheme amounted to £70 million, it seemed to me that the Chancellor of the Exchequer could not have considered an alternative to the increased
contributions which are provided for in the Clause, an alternative which would have been perfectly fair, which would have been graduated according to ability to pay and which would not have been imposed in inverse ratio to ability to pay.
What the Chancellor could have done was to withdraw the tax relief on employees' contributions under the National Insurance Scheme, and he would have had £70 million. Under this idea, the person who paid no Income Tax would pay no increased contributions. The person who paid at the lower rate of Income Tax would pay smaller contributions than those provided for in the Bill. Those in the higher ranges of income would obviously pay higher contributions than those provided for in the Bill. But it would have been perfectly fair.
1.30 a.m.
A man on the standard rate of Income Tax would have paid 93s. extra a year instead of 43s. a year, the increased contributions imposed by the Clause. A man on the lower rate of Income Tax would pay only 27s. instead of the 43s. which is imposed by the Clause. Those exempt from Income Tax would pay nothing extra, but under the Bill they will have to pay extra even though their circumstances do not entitle them to pay Income Tax.
I throw it out as an idea which the right hon. and learned Gentleman might have considered as a fairly painless way of providing the additional income which he believes to be necessary for the National Health Service. It would be general taxation—of course it is general taxation, part and parcel of it—but it is an interesting coincidence that the amount of revenue the Chancellor would get from that source would be a little more than the additional revenue that he is proposing to get by increased contributions.
These are serious considerations to put before the Committee even though the hour is so late. There is no doubt that a great many people will feel aggrieved at being taxed in this way. It is contrary to our concept of direct taxation. It is compulsory taxation. Some people prefer indirect taxation; they prefer to pay as they spend rather than pay as they earn. As has been pointed out on
numerous occasions, indirect taxation is tax which is paid when a person voluntarily spends money in a particular direction. More than one cynical Chancellor has pointed out that nobody is bound to drink beer or spirits, to buy a mink coat for anyone or to buy a motor car. There is an element of voluntary taxation in indirect taxation—much as I dislike it, because I believe that direct taxation, graduated and progressive, is by far the fairest means of getting the necessary money for national revenue.
But the contributions under Clause 1 are direct taxation, compulsory taxation, not graduated and not progressive, and, therefore, they bear more hardly on the lower-paid people. In those circumstances we must readjust our position about the Clause standing part of the Bill just as vehemently as we have opposed all the previous stages of the Bill and just as strongly as we shall oppose all subsequent stages of it. I hope that, no matter how late we may sit on any future occasions on the Bill, there will be both the mood and the time to consider some of the iniquities of these proposals and calmly to consider detailed criticisms of and alternatives to the scheme which the Financial Secretary is putting forward.

I rise to intervene for only a few minutes because I am anxious to ask my hon. Friend the Financial Secretary to the Treasury to clarify a technical point in connection with taxation which has been referred to generally by the hon. Member for Sowerby (Mr. Houghton).
Could the Financial Secretary confirm that my interpretation of the position, which I propose to enunciate in the next moment or two, in the context of Income Tax and Surtax is the correct one? The employee's contribution for National Insurance purposes is admitted as a charge when assessing liability to both Income Tax and Surtax. It is my understanding that the National Health Service contribution both under the 1957 Act and under Clause 1 is not so admitted as a charge for purposes of computing liability to Income Tax and Surtax.
If my interpretation of the position is correct and the National Insurance contribution is admitted and the National Health Service contribution is not admitted, would the Financial Secretary give a detailed explanation to the Com-
mittee when he replies to this debate as to the reasons for this contradistinction, because there is no doubt at all that, it my interpretation which I have just given is the correct one, it is not generally understood in the country. It may be understood by accountants, but it is not generally understood in the country, and it raises a very wide range of taxation considerations which I must say I shall want to consider, if not necessarily at a later stage of this Bill, at least when we reach the Finance Bill in April or May.

Everything I have heard during the discussion of this Clause, including the contribution which has just been made by the hon. Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro), makes me consider that we have to look very carefully at what we are doing in raising roughly £50 million of taxation in this manner. It is a lot of money. By this Clause we are being asked to agree that an additional burden of £50 million should be transferred to the shoulders of the people who are liable to this insurance tax.
As has been brought out in speeches on both sides of the Committee, there is not only a great deal of confusion outside but there is even a certain amount of doubt and confusion in this Committee itself. How much of the money is for general purposes and how much has been added specifically for health purposes? I have heard all of the arguments for the Clause, but I have heard none which justifies our agreeing to raise in this manner a single penny of the revenue required for the Health Service.
We went through the Second World War. We know the hazards of war. We all pay by direct taxation for the defence of our country. All of us in the Committee in various ways did our best to rebut the enemy during the war. Some suffered the tragedy of the blitz; some lost their lives; the health of some suffered some went to fight and suffered in health, or were severely hurt. But we would not have dreamt of raising taxation according to how the incidents of war affected us.
The incidence of injury and disease hits some more hardly than others. How can we then, in terms of economics, in terms of morality, in terms of any sane way of raising the nation's finances, possibly
justify singling out certain members of our community to contribute this additional £50 million? There is no insurance basis here. We do not say to an elderly lady, a young child, to any member of the community not liable to pay tax, "You should be denied any of the benefits of the Health Service".
This is a discriminatory form of taxation—a poll tax. It is not insurance. When we are paying insurance, we know what we pay and for what we pay it. Hon. Members opposite should join us in asking this basic question: are we prepared to agree that any part of the revenue for the Health Service should be raised in this way? In my home country, Scotland, when the children were naughty mother would wag her finger and say, "Give you an inch and you will take a mile." I say to hon Members opposite, "Give you an inch and you will take a mile."
When my hon. Friends agreed, whatever their reasons, that there should be a small addition to the National Insurance stamp set aside specifically for the Health Service, they did not take fully into consideration the nature of hon. Members opposite. It may or may not be the case that a Government formed by my party would have seen to it that there was no additional taxation; I will not deal in speculation. But it is clear from the behaviour of hon. Members opposite that they know that this tax is wrong in principle and that it is doubly wrong that at this hour of the morning we should be dealing not with the Ministry of Health but with the Treasury.
This provision is a temptation of the kind which the Treasury has never been able to resist—the temptation that it is able to get easy money in this way. We understand the reason for the tax; a Conservative Chancellor of the Exchequer and his Financial Secretary are under very great pressure from the party supporters to reduce Surtax and not to interfere with profits, whether made from property deals or in capital gains. We know the pressure which hon. Members opposite exert on the Chancellor. We are only doing our duty when we remind the Treasury Bench that we on this side of the Committee exist to impose other pressures.
We are trying to make it plain to hon. Members opposite that it matters to a
working man or woman when an extra 10d. is extracted from his or her weekly wages. The total of these tenpences, with the employers' contributions, is £50 million. What guarantee have we that hon. Members opposite will not in the future ask for another £50 million?
They probably will.

My hon. Friend the Member for Sowerby (Mr. Houghton) has made it clear that there is no logic in the position adopted by hon. Members opposite. I wait to see whether any hon. Member or hon. Lady opposite rises in his or her place to answer my hon. Friend's clear statement. I do not see many hon. Members opposite; I hope that they are not taking up too much space in the interview rooms. My hon. Friend made the clear statement that the Government are trying to transfer taxation. We are not discussing at the moment the total of taxation. We are not even discussing the expansion or contraction of the Health Service. We are on a much narrower Committee point, which is whether we can justify collecting £50 million in the way suggested in the Clause. My hon. Friend has pointed out perfectly fairly that there have been changes in taxation in the last five or ten years. A great deal has been made by hon. Members opposite of the fact that their Government have exempted some lower-wage earners from paying any taxation at all. If the debate did nothing else it would do some good by making it quite clear that the lower-wage earners, although they have had their direct taxation eased, at the same time help to pay taxes. They help by paying indirect taxes, Purchase Tax and now, worst of all, this poll tax.
1.45 a.m.
I hope that hon. Members opposite realise that they have done two things in bringing forward this Measure. The first is to make an exceedingly united Opposition, and we are not always united. [HON. MEMBERS: "Hear, hear".] A monolithic party is a dead party, and I am surprised that hon. Members opposite should think that they can face the economic and social problems of our time without arguing together.

The hon. Lady says that the Opposition are completely united. Her own statement in
debate in the last few weeks was clearly that it was her wish that the contribution should be utterly and totally abolished from the National Health Service. May I ask the hon. Member for Sowerby (Mr. Houghton) whether it is his intention to totally and utterly abolish the contribution from the National Health Service?
Answer.

That is a very good point. I know that the family of the noble Lord the Member for Hertford (Lord Balniel) has slipped back from Liberalism to Conservatism, but I have great hopes that he will climb back again one of these days.
The Government benches have made an absolutely united Opposition against a proposal that another £49 million or £50 million shall be raised in this way. I hope that what will follow this will be equally united recognition on the Opposition benches that in dealing with a Conservative Government it is not advisable to give them the excuse that they are now making use of by quoting a precedent set by this side of the Committee. When the Health Service was started, a modest sum was raised in this fashion as a temporary expedient, and only as a temporary expedient.
There were temporary resignations, too.
There were resignations on points of great principle, and now and again there have been members of the hon. Member's party who have also resigned.
I think that it would be better if the debate were carried on otherwise than by remarks across the Chamber.

Thank you, Mr. Blackburn. I think that you will agree with me that, as there has been an interruption, I should be allowed to reply to it. It would be appalling for the British House of Commons if there were not men and women of principle, on both sides of the House, now and again to give testimony, and nothing could more completely sustain the dignity of the House of Commons than that there should be men and women who feel that the House
comes before even their own parties. I shall not go into the merits of whether they are right or wrong.
It has been made clear to many of us that the principle behind attempting to raise even a penny towards the cost of the Health Service in this way is wrong. We are a united Opposition in opposing this increase in a poll tax. The service the Government have done us is that we are also a united Opposition in opposing the very principle of a poll tax. In future, we will give the Government—the Opposition of the future—no excuse for further misdeeds, because we will get right back to our basic Socialist principle that the Health Service, like the defence services, should be paid for according to one's ability to pay. Nothing can be more cowardly, more un-British, than deliberately to single out the shoulders of the weakest on which to impose an additional special tax.

It has been interesting throughout the debate to hear hon. Members opposite suggest that the contribution charge is a tax. It is much easier to make political propaganda by calling it a tax than by calling it a contribution.
To satisfy myself on the matter, I studied a summary of the proposals of the National Health Service Bill, 1946, brought in when hon. Members opposite were in power. The summary says—from Cmd. 6761—says: If the National Insurance Bill now before Parliament is passed into law, almost everyone will become compulsorily insurable, and after payment of the appropriate contributions will become entitled to the various cash benefits.
Order. The hon. Member is on the wrong Bill.

I have been in the Chamber during the course of the day and heard a number of hon. Members who have gone a little wide of the subject. Nevertheless, Mr. Blackburn, I will return to the subject we are discussing. It goes on: A proportion of their contributions. and this is applicable to this debate— will be used to help to finance the health services…financed partly from the exchequer, partly from local rates and partly from the national insurance contributions.

On a point of order. Would it not be better if the hon. Member
mentioned the Bill under discussion instead of harking back to another Measure?
That is not a point of order.
Further to that point of order
It cannot be "further to that point of order," for it was not a point of order.

On a new point of order, then I thought I heard you rule, Mr. Blackburn, that the hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford (Mr. K. Lewis) was out of order because he was dealing with the wrong Bill. Is it not, therefore, a de-finance of that Ruling if he continues, in spite of it, to read from the same Bill?
After I spoke to him, the hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford left the insurance part and came back to the question of health contributions.

I have every respect for you, Mr. Blackburn, and am quite prepared to carry out your orders. [Interruption.] I do not require to be kept in order by Members opposite. We have been told by Members opposite that Members on this side of the Committee have been rather slow in taking part in the discussions. I am now trying do so.
In calling this contribution a tax they are simply trying to secure for themselves a propaganda advantage in the country, since, quite clearly, the Explanatory Memorandum to the National Health Service Bill says unequivocally that the contribution, which the party opposite started, was an insurance contribution.
During the afternoon, while the hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford (Mr. K. Lewis) was out, some of us tried to discuss this matter. Perhaps I can put the point clearly to him now.
The hon. Member for Rochdale (Mr. McCann) should not presume to suggest that some of us have not been sitting in this Chamber quite continuously throughout the day. We have been out to eat.

I have sat here since the beginning of Question Time. The point was clearly made earlier that the
reason we regard this as a tax is that, first, this is a Treasury Bill, and secondly, the whole of the contribution is used to relieve the Treasury from the responsibility of paying towards the National Health Service.

I perfectly understand the point put by the hon. Member. I have been listening to our discussions for the last hour or two, and there have been so many repetitions that I cannot but understand it. But I still do not agree with it. Members opposite may call this a tax in order to secure their own advantage. Here we have a contribution which is compulsory throughout the country on everyone in work, and for that contribution there is given, in return, the National Health Service.
This contribution pays only about one-third of the cost. One hon. Member tried to make a comparison with the Road Fund. He was completely wrong in so doing, because the difference between this contribution and the Road Fund is that whereas the contribution pays for only part of the National Health Service, in the case of the Road Fund the Government did not spend as much money on roads as they collected from the motorists.
May we take it that the hon. Member does not agree with his right hon. and learned Friend the Chancellor of the Exchequer, who admits that this is a tax?

I do not accept that it is a tax in the normal sense of taxation. It is a contribution for which specific services are given in return. I have already asked the hon. Member for Ebbw Vale (Mr. M. Foot)—who made a speech in last week's debate—
Where is he?
—in which he suggested that if—
Where is the hon. Member?
I should be very grateful if the hon. Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro) would not make those comments.
On a point of order. Can my hon. Friend ask you where the hon. Member for Ebbw Vale (Mr. M. Foot) has gone to?

The hon. Member for Ebbw Vale said that if he and his hon. Friends were returned to office he would get rid of the contribution, but he then suggested that he would not get rid of it in the first Budget. I want to know from hon. Members opposite—perhaps the Opposition Front Bench can tell me —which Budget it is to be. Is it to be the second, the third or the fourth Budget —or will they in fact increase the contribution in one Budget and reduce it in the next, and then claim that they have taken it off?
Hon. Members opposite know quite well that they had to do all these things themselves, and that in the last few years we have increased these contributions much less than they did. Meanwhile, the expenditure on the Health Service under this Government is greater by far than it was when hon. Members opposite were in office.
A good, fighting Tory speech.

When the hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford (Mr. K. Lewis) rose to speak, we thought that we were going to have a constructive contribution to the debate from an hon. Member opposite, but we were rapidly disappointed. He has completely failed to understand the true purport of the Clause, which is the operative one in the Bill. During the Second Reading debate the Financial Secretary to the Treasury discussed the whole matter in terms of taxation, and explained why this was a Treasury Bill and not one under the jurisdiction of the Minister of Health or the Secretary of State for Scotland. We have had all this testimony to the essentially financial nature of the Measure, and the fact that it is to be considered at all stages in relation to taxation policy.
The hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford, who is now carrying on a conversation with his hon. Friend, is oblivious to this point. I would point out to him that it is usual, after one has made a speech, to listen to the next speech which is made. I would draw his attention not merely to the proceedings of the Committee but also to the comments made in the national Press, by the most reputable newspapers—The Times and the Guardian—to the effect
that although the Minister of Health originally announced the whole conspectus of charges, of which we are now discussing only one, the operation had nothing to do with the Health Service, and that it was a financial operation.
In case the hon. Member has been too busy to pay attention to his newspapers each morning, which ordinary conscientious Members always do, I would draw his attention to the leading article in The Times of 2nd February, which first refers to the announcement made by the Minister of Health and says that it should cause no surprise—and we are entirely in agreement on that—and goes on to say: None of the additional charges promises any conspicuous improvement in either the financial efficiency of the service or of the standard of medical and dental care. The operation is largely a matter of bookkeeping intended not so much to restrain the cost of the National Health Service as to restrain the annual increase in the amount borne by the Exchequer". In other words, it is related to the taxation policy of Her Majesty's Government. There was a very interesting addition later in the same article, which said: It is worth wondering, for example, how long it will be before further increases in charges will be made on the basis of budgeting convenience and whether the transfer of the financial burden from progressive taxation to flat rate taxation should be encouraged. It was perfectly plain on the morning after the announcement was made that the leader writer of The Times was under no illusion as to what this was all about. He did not pretend that it was in any way to improve the Health Service, but pointed out that it was a matter of budgeting convenience. Similarly, on the same morning, The Guardian said in a leading article under the heading: "A Tory Bill for Health"—

Before my hon. Friend goes on to read The Guardian article, may I ask if she agrees that it is quite obvious that the hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford (Mr. K. Lewis)—who is no longer in his place—is not one of the "Top People"? Otherwise he would have read the article in The Times.
Clearly he is not one of the "Top People", and he is also non-U because he has left the Chamber during the speech succeeding his speech.
Typical Tory tactics.
Order. If there were less noise, I am sure it would be much easier for the hon. Member who has the Floor of the Committee to make her points.
I shall try to draw the attention of the Committee to the comment which was contained in the leading article in The Guardian on the same morning.

I understand that the hon. Lady made some comment about my having left the Chamber. I thought she might have waited for a few seconds before saying that, because I simply went to the door in response to a communication from the Official Reporters which was handed to me.

I am sure we are all delighted to have the hon. Member with us again. There is still much that he has to learn about Clause 1 of the Bill.
Before that interruption, I was about to draw the attention of the Committee to the comment in The Guardian leading article on the morning of 2nd February. It said: Flat-rate contributions are tolerable only while they are kept low enough so as not to press too heavily on the poorer families. The article also said: If the Government wished to raise… We know about the "slow hand-clap" —[Interruption]. I was about to say that the comment of the leading article was: If the Government wished to raise the contributions it should have found some way of relating the amount paid to earnings. The burden of our complaint about this Clause is, as my hon. Friend the Member for Sowerby (Mr. Houghton) pointed out, that we think it is a most objectionable way of raising the money required for the Health Service. When the Financial Secretary made a speech on Second Reading—[Interruption.]

On a point of order, Mr. Blackburn, I want to draw your attention to the completely outrageous clowning that is going on by the hon. Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro), with the specific intention of preventing serious argument.

I have already appealed to the Committee that
there should be less noise so that we might have the opportunity of hearing the speech of the hon. Member—[Interruption]—and I should be very glad if the hon. Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro), if he does not intend to take part in the debate or listen to the speeches, would leave the Chamber.

I was trying to make a critical examination of the reasons given by the Financial Secretary in defence of this Clause. He has attempted to justify the Bill with a seriously reasoned speech, and I think that it is only fair that one should subject that speech to serious critical examination.
The hon. Gentleman gave three main reasons for suggesting that the methods proposed by Her Majesty's Government for raising the money were valid. His first reason was that there had been an increase in the average earnings and that, therefore, the proposed poll tax was not an undue burden. Ample evidence has been adduced that an average is by no means a valid consideration when one is, in fact, introducing a flat-rate contribution. The flat-rate contribution is inequitable in its incidence on those whose wages are well below the average. That point 'has been made so frequently that I shall not pursue it further.
The Financial Secretary's second reason was that in the last four years—since l957—national expenditure has been rising more rapidly than the national income. I should have thought that for the honour of his own party, that has been in Government all this time, the hon. Gentleman would hardly have put forward that argument. He chose 1957 for comparison, but that was the year when we suffered from the backwash of the financial administration of the present Leader of the House.
National expenditure was most savagely cut back then, so that, having been cut back to such a degree as to be a disgrace to the country, it is not really surprising that it Should have risen slightly since then. As for the national income not having risen to keep pace with that expenditure—whose fault is that? It is the fault of the Government. That argument is well below the normal standard of the hon. Gentleman, for Whom I have a considerable regard.
I would call in evidence other commentaries on the matter. The Financial
Secretary suggested that we have been spending too large a proportion of the national income on the social services; that as it had reached a stage where it was too large a 'burden, we had to have this iniquitous poll tax to meet that cost.
We have very recently had a survey of the national income by P.E.P. The main purpose has been to explain why the economy has not been expanding so fast as it should. I will not go into that at length now, but I think that it is germane to the matter which we are discussing to point out that this survey went very carefully into the whole question raised by the Financial Secretary of the relationship of the expenditure on the social services and the national income. It pointed out that in the last few years, since the transfer to State provision, the expenditure on the Services we are discussing has not been any larger than it would have been without the National Health Service.
It said that statistics do not show that State provision is noticeably more generous than private provision. There is no evidence that consumption is taking a larger share of national resources than it would if individuals were still making their own provisions, or that the British social services are excessive when compared with those of other wealthy nations.
The Welfare State has not been a burden on the economy in the postwar years, and the reasons for the slow rate of growth must be sought elsewhere. Those are some of the findings of this survey, and I think they answer the Financial Secretary.
He then proceeded to suggest that another reason for these increased contributions was that they were needed if we were to have more hospitals, and so on. We do not quarrel with him on that point. We do not quarrel with the fact that the Government, at long last, are thinking of making additions to the hospital programme which has been so shockingly neglected in recent years. What we complain about is not that, but the method chosen for raising this money. It is a method which we think is inequitable.
The Financial Secretary made great play at one point with the proportion of our taxed income raised by direct or indirect taxation, and I think that my hon. Friend the Member for Sowerby
gave a most admirable illustration of how the proportion of direct taxation falls upon people at different levels of income and how those on the lower scales have not in the least benefited in the last few years. Again, the Financial Secretary took a particular year for comparisons in the total proportions of our taxed income which came from direct and indirect taxation sources. He mentioned 1951–1952, and compared that year with the present time. But if he had taken a year later, the result would have been different. I would point out that he took a particular year which proved his point, but that he would perhaps not have done so well if he had taken a different year when the figures would have been against his argument.

Despite certain difficulties which we are experiencing, I have been trying to attend carefully to the speech of the hon. Lady. What she is saying is a little unfair. If I had taken, say, 1950–1951 it would have borne out my point in a worse manner, and not better, because in the last year of the Labour Government taxation was substantially put up.

I do not think that that proves anything, because one year might have been more in my favour and another more in his favour.
One point which should have been brought to the attention of the Committee is that the Financial Secretary has not been using as his argument for the increase in social services the need to cater for an increasing population. I have been surprised that we have had so little reference in our discussions to a matter which I myself raised on an earlier occasion, the natural increase in expenditure because of the changing nature of our population. In the P.E.P. report to which I have referred, some very striking figures are given of the increased proportion of those under 15 years of age and over 65 years of age. Taking the year 1958 in comparison with 1939, the percentage increase in dependent population over pre-war years is no less than 24 per cent. That is a very considerable increase, and it would account, of course, for the extra expenditure required in the Health Service. There is, therefore, nothing at all in the argument advanced by the Financial Secretary.
Our main objection to the Clause is to the method of financing chosen by the Government. We had supposed that the Government would have done some new thinking on the method of raising the money. We hear a great deal from the Bow Group and elsewhere about the need for people to pay the charges as they use the services—but that would be out of order on this Bill—and there are, of course, other methods for raising the money. We had a very interesting speech from the hon. Member for Cheadle (Mr. Shepherd), for instance—
Where is he?
He has not been present for some little time. He suggested that there should be the equivalent of a pay roll tax. That appears to be the fashionable gambit this year.
I think the hon. Lady should discuss the Question "That the Clause stand pant of the Bill," without suggesting new methods for raising the money.

With respect, Mr. Blackburn, this is surely the whole burden of our argument, that we dislike intensely this method of raising the money, and it is therefore up to us who oppose it to make alternative suggestions.
That may be so, but on this Question we can discuss only what is in the Clause.
Naturally, I was not proposing to go into all the details of the pay roll tax.

On a point of order, Mr. Blackburn. Would your Ruling mean that we may not advance any arguments against this Clause which are not contained within the limits of the Clause and we may not give our reasons for objecting to it?
The hon. Member may give reasons why he objects to the Clause, but he would not be entitled to put forward a new scheme.

Further to that point of order, Mr. Blackburn. Is it not a legitimate part of the argument in objecting to one way of raising money to say that there are better ways of raising it? Is that not relevant?
Quite clearly that would be in order, but it would not be in order to go into detail.

With respect, Mr. Blackburn, I was not proposing to go into detail, and, indeed, I do not think that I am competent to do so. The suggested pay roll tax is a comparatively new thing for those of us who are not specialists in economics. I referred to it because it was mentioned earlier in the debate. Also, my hon. Friend the Member for Sowerby made a suggestion concerning a possible way of dealing with the employer's contribution which was queried in its detail by the hon. Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro). I think it was perfectly in order for my hon. Friend to suggest that this was another method by which the Treasury could obtain an equivalent sum, or perhaps even a slightly higher sum in revenue, instead of adopting the method chosen in Clause 1. I suggest, therefore, that it is in order at least to refer to the alternative methods of raising taxation which would not be open to the serious social objections which we find to the proposals in the Clause.
One of the other objections to the Clause is that the increase for employees is considerable whereas the increase for employers is slight. According to the Money Resolution, I understand, we are not able to put down Amendments which would bring this point into the open, but in discussing this Question we should at least be able to refer to the fact that the Clause is increasing the employee's contribution but is not shifting the burden, as it might, on to the employer, which would be an alternative method of tax.
There are wider questions, which I would not wish to go into, whereby we consider that the Government have no business to raise money in this way, because we consider that the money should be part of general taxation. One could easily get into the question of whether there should be a capital gains tax, for example. That would be one of the alternative methods of increasing the revenue from general taxation which would make it unnecessary to raise the money in this way.
There are a number of Amendments to the Schedule which will prove our
point in detail. At the moment, all I am concerned to say is that in principle we find the Clause, which is the operative Clause of the Bill, objectionable. The arguments put forward by the Financial Secretary do not sustain the Government in their intentions in the Clause. I hope very much, therefore, that we shall oppose it and defeat it.

We have had a useful beginning to what, I hope, will prove an interesting if extensive debate on the Question "That the Clause stand part of the Bill". I was interested in the speech of the hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford (Mr. K. Lewis), who seemed to object to our use of the description "poll tax" and suggested that it would be more palatable if we called the tax a contribution. We call it a tax because it is a charge levied on citizens by the State as a contribution to the Revenue, and is not earmarked for any particular service, as has become abundantly clear throughout our debates of the last fortnight. We call it a poll tax because rich and poor alike pay it. The richer citizen pays exactly the same as the poorer citizen, which is the fundamental principle of a poll tax, a tax of so much a head.
If the hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford objects to the name "poll tax" because it had evil connotations in the past—its association with the great rebel Wat Tyler and its association with the negro in the Southern States of America —1 would say to him that A rose by any other name would smell as sweet. Whatever he chooses to call this, we regarded it as an iniquitous and unjust burden that the Clause is imposing on the poorer citizens.
The Clause is obviously the heart of the Bill. It is the mean heart of a very bad Bill. I was hoping that Government back-benchers would get up to discuss with us the question of the poll tax element enshrined in the Clause. It is no answer to the case put forward by my hon. Friend the Member for Sowerby (Mr. Houghton) in opening this debate for the hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford merely to say, "You did it when you were in power".
As I said in an earlier debate, there is a fundamental difference between a poll tax of 10d. and a poll tax of 3s. 4d. A 400 per cent. increase in the poll tax
in my opinion changes its nature almost to the extent of changing the principle.
2.30 a.m.
I hope that the Committee will examine very seriously whether the poll tax is to be a permanent element in British taxation. Are the Government prepared to defend it as something which is vital and fundamental? Is it to be increased, as this Clause increases it, every time we expand the Health Service? Is every extension now in the Welfare State and the National Health Service to be matched by some increase in the poll element of taxation? [Interruption].
Order. Perhaps hon. Members who are conversing at the other end of the Chamber will allow us to have just one Committee meeting here.

I can sum up our opposition under this heading to the Clause standing part of the Bill by paraphrasing a famous resolution which appears in the records of the House of Commons—that we say that poll taxes have increased, are increasing and ought to be diminished. I believe that the poll tax is a bad principle and that a bad principle becomes worse the more one extends and expands its application.
The Clause will add millions of pounds in extra taxation to the burden which is carried by those in the country who are least able to carry financial burdens. It will impose a burden on the poorest people, not to build hospitals but merely to avoid putting exactly the same financial burden in the form of graduated taxation on the shoulders of persons according to their ability to pay.
The Government will use the £50 million to relieve the Surtax payers.

I do not wish to anticipate what use the Government will make of the money that they will gain from this proposal, and I think I should be out of order in pursuing that subject. However, I already detect on the Order Paper some signs of alarm on the benches opposite about the impact of this kind of charge on the poorest people. A group of hon. Members opposite have tabled a Motion
in which they say they are anxious that all National Health Service charges shall not be imposed on the poorest people just above the National Assistance Board scale. But this is just our case against this Clause—for it imposes a new burden on the poorest persons in the community. It has to be considered not in isolation, not merely as a new 10d. impost or tax; it has to be considered as the latest in the series of increases in the poll tax element from the 10d. that it was when we were in power to the 3s. 4d. which the Clause will impose.
I believe that this increase in the poll tax element of the raising of funds by the State is bad. I am anxious lest it should endanger support in the minds of the poorest for the Welfare State. The poorest will resent flat-rate increases, and resent them more and more as each increase takes place. Increases may build up in the minds of some of our poorer people resistance even against the benefits of the Welfare State.
That may be the Government's object.

It may be. But it would be a tragedy if anyone who has to pay even the impost imposed by the Clause became opposed to the National Heatlh Service, because, as we know, the Government can rightly claim that the bulk of the cost of the Welfare State is still levied by the State upon people according to their capacity to bear it. So that, however heavy the burden which this Clause imposes upon the poorest people, the Welfare State still has tremendous benefits for the poorest people in the community.
I am even more alarmed by the fact that this Clause will add some £49 million or £50 million a year additional income to the Treasury. Once the Treasury has a source of income it is very loath to part with it. If anyone wants the simple classic example it is that of Purchase Tax, which was levied during the war for certain specific social purposes, none of which were the raising of revenue, and now, although almost everybody in the Committee is opposed to Purchase Tax, it is exceedingly difficult to persuade the Treasury, no matter which side of the Committee is in power,
to part with this source of a vast income. So, once the Treasury finds itself with another £50 million annual revenue, it will be very difficult for the Government of any party to persuade the Treasury to deprive itself of that income.
I am concerned deeply with the principle of the poll tax itself, and I want to read to the Committee a description of the attitude of mind of the Government as seen by a famous Socialist in France, the great Anatole France. In his satire, "Penguin Island", he described the Parliament of the Penguins held in the Dark Ages. The Penguins were his satirical representation of humanity. A speaker, obviously a Conservative, got up and said: The public interest demands that you must not ask for much from those who possess much; because then the rich would be less rich and the poor more poor. The poor live on the prosperity of the rich—that is why that prosperity is sacred. If you take from the rich, you will not get much, because there are so few of them and you will plunge the country into misery. One the other hand, if you impose a little tax on everybody, regardless of what he has got, you will get enough for the public need and you will not have to have a means test which every citizen dislikes. In charging everybody the same little bit, you will spare the poor, since they will enjoy the prosperity of the rich. This was supposed to be spoken in an ancient Parliament 1,500 years ago. Anatole France went on to say that a second Tory speaker got up in that Parliament and said: I propose we write this speech on tablets of brass. In 1,500 years' time the best Penguins will still say the same thing. Anatole France was right. The "best people" are still saying that the best thing is to spread the burden of taxation among the little people of this country; that if we put the hardship on the shoulders of the poorest people in this country by levying the same amount upon the millionaire and the widow, then we are preserving the differential wealth of the rich, and that in so doing we are in some strange way contributing to the prosperity of the people. Indeed, the whole case of the Government, the whole case the Financial Secretary will put when he concludes this debate, is that if we levy this flat rate we do not have to levy the amount involved by graduated taxation, and graduated taxation discourages those wealthier people in the country whose effort and whose work keep the country prosperous.
May I interrupt my hon. Friend to remind him of Boyle's Law: the pressure varies inversely with the volume? He will see the point.

I am grateful for the help of my hon. and learned Friend, but I turn to my second point. My second point is that there is no evidence that anybody outside the House of Commons wants the Clause. I have already seen in earlier debates signs on the opposite benches that at least some of the Conservative Members of Parliament who are deeply devoted to the Health Service —and there are Members opposite who are uneasy about the new health taxes.
I do not believe that dishonesty is a necessary part of politics. The Labour Party always put most of their programme—in fact, too much of their programme—in the manifesto which they present to the electorate. If they have one fault, it is that they spend too much time discussing how much they can put into the programme of the policy which they hope to implement if returned to Parliament. The first Labour Government had the unique record in British politics of carrying out completely. In the years which followed, the programme which they put before the electorate in 1945.
But it is certainly not true that any indication of the new poll tax, which is contained in this Clause, was given by the Government or any of their supporters when they sought the support of the people at the last General Election. I turned up their Election Manifesto for 1959 and I will quote the essential part—and I never quote unfairly. The Tories said: We have cut taxes in three Budgets while continuing to develop the social services. Do you want to go ahead on the lines which have brought prosperity at home? Incidentally, that was not true. They had already nearly doubled the poll tax element of taxation. But obviously the implication of the manifesto and the appeal which they were making to the British electorate was, "We shall continue to develop the Health Service and to cut taxation". If they had it in their minds at that time that the only way to continue to develop the Health Service was to impose a new and penal poll tax, I believe that they should have had the
honesty to tell the British people what they intended to do.
I turned up that part of their election manifesto dealing specifically with health. They promised that they would clean the air, make vaccination easier, improve and increase the number of hospitals, improve doctors' pay and recruit social workers —but not a word in the manifesto that they intended to impose a poll tax to pay for part of the Health Service.
A fraudulent prospectus.

If this Clause were in their minds at that time, why did they not say so? The electors were entitled to know that when they voted for a Tory Government they were voting for a Government which intended to raise the poll tax by this Clause. Not a single speech by a Tory candidate, from one end of the country to the other, making promises to the electors, stated that if the electors voted for a Tory, one of his actions would be to raise the Health Service charges by 10d. I have not read their speeches, but I suggest that neither the Financial Secretary nor even the Minister of Health told his constituents that he intended to raise the flat-rate poll tax charge by 10d. to pay for the National Health Service.
We can go much further than that. I have turned up the Queen's Speech of November, 1959, and there is not a word in it about this proposal. In the second Queen's Speech there is no reference to the fact that the Government intended to do this. I suspect the malign influence of the new Minister of Health—since the election, since the first Queen's Speech, since the second Queen's Speech—in introducing this new charge. I go even further. If this is such a wonderful policy, why was it not announced qt the annual Conservative Party conference in October, when the new Minister of Health said, "It is a wonderful moment to be associated with the National Health Service"—speaking with unconscious, dramatic irony as he was about to inflict a dagger wound upon that Service?
2.45 a.m.
If the Government had been really honest when they had this great mass conference of their own supporters and were talking about the Health Service, they would have told the Tory trade unionists and the keen Tory voluntary workers for the Health Service who were
assembled at their annual conference that they proposed to impose a penal charge.
Surely my right hon. Friend will agree that the Act has been abused since the early years and that we are trying to bring the Health Service back to a sensible level?

The hon. and gallant Member honours me by calling me his right hon. Friend. He is wrong about the "right honourable" but I do not object to the "Friend". This is a political fight, not a personal one. If the hon. and gallant Member had been here earlier in the debate he would have found that we have already dealt with that point. Far from bringing this poll tax back to where it was when we introduced the National Health Service, these proposals complete the process of quadrupling the poll tax element in the Health Service charge.
The Clause reveals the rival philosophies that exist on opposite sides of the Committee. We on this side believe in, and when we get into power we shall seek to implement, a movement away from poll tax. We believe in the philosophy of to each according to his need and from each according to his capacity to pay, whereas this Clause and the rest of the measures which we have been discussing in the last fortnight are founded on the very different and grim philosophy of to him that hath shall be given and from him that hath not shall be taken away even that which he hath.
rose—
On a point of order. Is it fair and reasonable, Sir Gordon, that the Financial Secretary should rise at this juncture? Many of us have been waiting to—
An hon. Member cannot discuss the selection of speakers by the Chair.
It is very likely that the Patronage Secretary will pop in as soon as the Financial Secretary has sat down and move the Closure.
I repeat that the selection of speakers by the Chair cannot be discussed.

I want to go back straight away to the point made by the hon. Member for Sowerby (Mr. Houghton) shortly after—if I may so express it—we achieved take-off in the debate on the Clause. The hon. Member made the point, which I was interested to hear and was glad he made, that in his view the social services should be financed mainly out of general taxation. I think that we have spent a long time on the Clause—[HON. MEMBERS: "Oh."]—and I am not complaining of that at all. We have had a debate on Second Reading of the Bill and a debate on the Ways and Means Resolution, but I believe that the Committee will have its whole view of the Clause out of perspective if it fails to realise from the start that the social services today in Britain, and after the passing of this Bill, will continue to be financed mainly out of general taxation.
Do not let us forget that for the forthcoming financial year, 1961–62, only £148 million of net Exchequer expenditure on the Health Service will be financed from contributions and £600 million worth of that expenditure will be financed from the Exchequer. The point is perfectly simple and, having had the pleasure of debating with him for some hours last night, I think that the hon. Member for Nelson and Colne (Mr. S. Silverman) is well capable of appreciating the point. As I have said on numerous occasions when debating the Bill, deciding just where the balance should be drawn between the amount of the Health Service expenditure to be financed from contributions and the amount to be financed from general taxation is a matter of degree. I am simply making the point that in Britain today by far the greater proportion of the social services, and not only the Health Service, is in fact financed out of general taxation.

How does the hon. Member work that out, because he knows perfectly well that the total revenue of the National Insurance Fund is very nearly £1,000 million a year and its expenditure about the same? How can he argue that the social services, including the Health Service, are mainly financed out of general taxation?

The right hon. Gentleman has referred to one social service,
namely, the National Insurance benefits. I do not want to pursue this matter to the point of getting out of order, but I do not want to evade the right hon. Gentleman's questions. When he considers the total of the social services—National Insurance benefits, the Health Service, education and so on, he will find that there is no doubt that social service expenditure today is mainly financed out of general taxation.
I hope that the hon. Gentleman will not pursue this argument too far, because it is getting a little wide of the Question "That the Clause stand part of the Bill."

The Financial Secretary still says that the social services are still mainly financed out of general taxation, which must mean that the total revenue from general taxation exceeds that derived from insurance contributions. The total expenditure which derives from insurance contributions, from employees and employers, is now nearly £1,000 million a year. To substantiate his argument, will the hon. Gentleman state what sum additional to that, expended on the social services, comes from general taxation?

I do not carry the actual figure in my head, but Exchequer expenditure on Health plus the Exchequer contribution out of general taxation to the general grant services are alone bigger than £1,000 million.
The second argument of hon. Members opposite has been that we have a regressive taxation system. That simply is not true. With the share taken by Income Tax and Surtax in our taxation system and the amount raised by the more progressive forms of indirect taxation, I do not believe that any fair-minded person could say that our taxation is overall regressive
Is not that the case only because there is not a capital gains tax?

I do not understand the relevance of that remark. Considering the tax system as a whole, with direct taxation and the more progressive forms of indirect taxation, nobody can say that our system of taxation is unfairly regressive.

We are discussing not the general system of taxation, but Clause 1 of the Bill, and the argument from this side of the Committee has been that this particular tax is regressive. Will the hon. Gentleman address himself to that argument?

I am coming to this particular form of tax—[HON. MEMBERS: "Oh."]—this farm of contribution, in a moment. Hon. Members opposite need not worry about that. My right hon. Friend the Minister of Health used the word "tax" in connection with this contribution when we debated the Motion of censure, and I myself explicitly said some hours ago that this was a Treasury Bill for which we took full responsibility. There is no dispute between us as to the facts of this matter.
I dealt with this argument about our taxation system because a number of hon. Members had referred to it during the debate in the last two hours.
Will the hon. Gentleman now make it clear to his hon. Friend the Member for Rutland and Stamford (Mr. K. Lewis) that this is a tax? Will he now try to educate Members opposite?

I have made it clear. At this hour it is a slight abuse of the right of intervention to ask one hon. Member to educate one of his hon. Friends.
There has been an interesting division of opinion—and I am not trying to make an unfair point—between the hon. Member for Sowerby and the hon. Lady the Member for Cannock (Miss Lee) who, we all recognise, made a serious and distinguished contribution to the debate. He came more directly than any of his hon. Friends to recognising quite explicitly that we should have to go on, whichever Government were in power, financing part of the Service by means of contributions. However much he disputed these proposals he did not disagree with the financing of part of the Service by this means.
The hon. Lady, on the other hand, said that we should not raise a penny for the National Health Service in this manner. She objected to the contribution, not on the ground that it was a poll tax, but on the opposite ground that it was a discriminatory tax, and that
under this system some people came off better than others.
The contribution is discriminatory, but in the right way. It is in favour of the contribution that it does not fail on the retired person, the sick, the unemployed or those on National Assistance; it excludes these classes of people through its links with National Insurance. In so far as it is discriminatory it is so in a good sense and not in a bad sense.

The hon. Gentleman does not see the point. It is simple enough, but perhaps he has not the answer. What is being alleged is that if everybody, irrespective of income and capital, has to pay the same amount, then that is discriminatory because it means that the heavier burden falls on those least able to pay. Does the hon. Gentleman admit that that is so? If so, does he approve of it?

I do not admit that that is so. I indicated that it is in favour of the contribution that it does not fall on everybody, precisely through its links with National Insurance. It is not unreasonable that there should be a contribution towards the cost of the Service. While this must be a matter for precise judgment, I do not believe that in present circumstances the rate proposed in the Bill is unreasonable.

Is it not discriminatory, in the hon. Gentleman's view, to charge the same amount on an income of £10 a week as on an income of £50 a week? Is not 10s. 7d. out of £10 a week a considerably heavier burden than 10s. 7d. out of £50 a week?
No; it is not discriminatory. That is a complete misuse of language.
It falls more hardly on the £10-a-week man.

If the hon. Member will wait I will tell him what it is. It is not discriminatory; it is regressive. If hon. Members opposite think that "regressive" and "discriminatory" mean the same thing, the educative process referred to by the Leader of the Opposition needs to be carried a good deal further. There is a considerable difference between the meanings of the two words. There is
nothing wrong about having a regressive element in our system of contributions and taxation to this extent.
If the percentage of income one pays is higher when one's income is lower, surely that is discriminatory in any ordinary sense of the English language?

I have made my point, and the right hon. Member has made his. I believe that I was perfectly justified in saying that this was admittedly and avowedly a regressive element in our system. [Interruption.] The hon. Member will not put me off by his familiar habit of barracking while remaining seated.

I have been sitting upstairs for hours watching this debate, and the hon. Member looks very different from up there. This jargon about discriminatory and regressive, and all the rest of it, which the hon. Member uses, will not convince the £10-a-week man, who is paying 10s. 7d. in National Insurance contributions, that the Government are not discriminating against him in comparison to the wealthy man.

I come back to the point I made during the Second Reading debate: this rate of contribution is not unreasonable, considering the generally high level of wage-earning incomes and also the rising level of enjoyment of social service benefits. I can remember when I was first a Member and sat on the Opposition benches, and when hon. Members opposite were on the Government benches, hearing the late, greatly respected Mr. Percy Daines saying, "We must consider not only wage incomes but social incomes." Social incomes have risen substantially in the 1950s, under the present Government.
The hon. Member for Sowerby quoted one or two recent exchanges at Question Time. One was a Question asked of my right hon. Friend the Minister of Pensions and National Insurance. I would remind the hon. Member that the Answer given included employers' contributions as well as those of the employees, and that affected the strength of the point the hon. Member was making. He also referred to the exchange at Question Time between my right hon. and learned Friend the Chancellor of the Exchequer and the right hon. Member for Battersea, North (Mr. Jay). The Answer given then was
that for 1951–52 a married man with one child under 11 years of age, earning £9 a week, paid 7·8 per cent. of his income in Income Tax and National Insurance contributions combined, while at the present rate the figure was 6· per cent. I do not agree with the hon. Member for Sowerby that there is virtually no difference between 7· per cent. and 6· per cent. In percentage terms the difference is about 28 per cent.
It is also important to remember the point made by my hon. Friend the Member for the Isle of Ely (Sir H. Legge-Bourke) that we must consider the considerably greater number of people today with incomes substantially above £500 a year. In 1949 there were 20 million people earning less than £400 a year, 2·5 million earnings between £400 and £500, and 2·8 million earning between £500 and £1,000. Ten years later, in 1959, there were not 20 million but only 9 million earning less than £400, and 11·5 million, as compared with 2·8 million, earning between £500 and £1,000. We must take that sort of comparison into account.

Would it not be much more relevant to look at the case of the man earning £50 a week and see what the corresponding percentages were in 1951 and today? Would it not then be found to have been reduced by 50 per cent.?

That is the sort of point we can debate, and I shall be glad to debate it when we come to the Budget. It is worth remembering that wage earners and people earning incomes in this country are by no means earning exactly the same amount all their lives. As hon. Members know, there have been far more people than ever before in our national history moving from wage-earning standards to higher standards in the last decade.

I am very ignorant on these things, but suppose a tax takes the same percentage from varying incomes, is it progressive, regressive, discriminatory or none of those things? If in fact it takes the same percentage of varying incomes, obviously it will take different amounts according to whether the income is a large or a small one.

I thought we had passed that about ten minutes ago. A tax
which takes the same proportion of varying incomes is of course not a progressive tax, but I thought we had dealt with that.

May I put this point to the hon. Gentleman, because I think he is trying to be objective and fair to a limited extent? We have sufficient regard for his intellectual perspicacity to know that he knows in his own heart that in putting this partial argument he is missing the main point. The main point is that when he quotes a comparison of money incomes of 1951 with 1961 he is completely ignoring the tremendous inflation which has increased in amount in that period, and it is not money values but real values with which we are concerned.
Of course I recognise that the value of money has changed. That is the danger in quoting any statistics in the Committee—that it is difficult to make all the qualifications which should be made.
rose—

I have given way several times. Allow me to answer the hon. Member for Westhoughton (Mr. J. T. Price) before I give way again. It is sufficiently relevant to point out that at one time there were 20 million people with incomes of less than £400, and ten years later there are only 9 million of them.

If I follow the hon. Gentleman correctly, he is saying that there are more people than there used to be earning £500 a year and that that is a justification for increasing this particular form of taxation. It is also true that there are more people than there used to be earning more than £5,000 a year. Would he say that that is a reason for increasing Surtax? If he does not say that, surely he is discriminating in his whole attitude?

The hon. Member knows that in drawing me to talk about Surtax he is raising matters which we had better discuss on the Budget. I am not going to be drawn to discuss the whole field of taxation on this occasion. You, Sir Gordon, would not be pleased if I attempted to do so.
At a time when we are under attack from hon. Members opposite for introducing a measure which is excessively regressive, I say that one of the reasons which makes these increases not unreasonable is the general increase in wage incomes in the last ten years and in the social services as a whole.

While I concede to the hon. Gentleman that he probably could not keep in order and answer the point put to him by my hon. Friend the Member for Fulham (Mr. M. Stewart) about what it would be right to do about Surtax, is not the point relevant and in order in another way? What we are discussing, surely, is whether this poll tax, or whatever we call it, is discriminatory in the wrong sense in that it imposes a far heavier burden on the backs least able to bear it. In order to say that that was not so, the hon. Gentleman said in reply to my hon. Friend that, after all, incomes had gone up by 28 per cent. My hon. Friend asked whether richer people had not had incomes increased in the same period by a much higher percentage, to which his reply was that he would tell us on some future occasion. Would it not be right to tell us on this occasion?

I think that I can answer the hon. Gentleman without going out of order at all. I have never disputed, and I do not now dispute, that this particular contribution is regressive. I am sure that I speak for all my hon. Friends when I say that nobody disputes that—it is perfectly evident. What I say is that we have to consider it against the background of many other factors, most of which I have mentioned. I do not believe that it is true to say that the direct taxpayer is not making a fair contribution, through progressive taxation, to the social services, and I say to the hon. Member—although this is not something that we can debate at length —that as I said in the Motion of censure debate, I believe we have a better and fairer distribution of incomes today than we had ten or eleven years ago.
In a fairly short speech, my hon. Friend the Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro) asked me about the circumstances in which contributions were admitted as a deduction for Income Tax. The answer is that the employee con-
tribution for insurance is mostly admitted, but not the part relevant to sickness benefit. The National Health Service contribution is not allowable, and we think that it is not right that it should be allowed against taxation. The tax position of National Health Insurance contributions was established by the form of Section 3 (4) of the National Health Service Contributions Act, 1957.
The hon. Member for Sowerby asked about tax relief for insurance contributions. The short answer to that is that if the tax relief for insurance contributions were withdrawn it would be impossible to justify taxing retirement pensions. Whilst we cannot go into that in this debate it is my own firm view, after examining many cases, that much greater injustice would be done if we did not tax retirement pensions—

My hon. Friend has just said, with justification, that if one disallowed the charges of an insurance contribution as an admissible charge for the purpose of computing Income Tax and Surtax it would be inequitable that the retirement pension should not be taxed. What is the position in relation to sickness benefit? Is that ever subject to Income Tax and Surtax? [HON. MEMBERS: "No."] I am trying to draw my hon. Friend on this complicated matter. Is that the real reason why the Treasury refuses to admit the National Health Service contribution as a charge for the purpose of computing the liability to Income Tax and Surtax?

I do not want to be drawn too far by my hon. Friend. It is precisely the financial nature of the National Health Service contribution—which I have not denied in this debate, and insisted on earlier—which makes it inappropriate, in our view, to allow it to rank against taxation, and that has been the case ever since the contribution had a separate, legal entity under the 1957 Act. After listening to these debates, I cannot help feeling that when hon. Members have criticised, not merely this contribution—which is fair enough—but the Government's policy, they are not criticising the Government really as much as they sometimes like to think that they are.
3.15 a.m.
I say that because today I believe we have in this country a better system of
social services than we have ever had before. Far more people gain more from our system both for themselves and for their families than they have had before. In view of the economic progress which our country has made, and the progress which has been made in the social services, I do not believe at all that this new rate of contribution is an unreasonable rate. For that reason, I now ask the Committee heartily to approve this Clause.

There is one thing at least upon which the Financial Secretary should he congratulated, and that is that he has given us the privilege of a good debating speech. One of the misnomers of our proceedings tonight has been that we have continually heard reference to the debate, but there has been no debate. We have just heard the first real speech on this Question from that side of the Committee. I think that the hon. Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro) will agree when I say that his point was a purely technical point and, on reflection, I also think that the hon. Member for Rutland and Stamford (Mr. K. Lewis) will agree that he was quite mistaken in approaching his speech in the manner in which he did.
Will the hon. Gentleman allow me? Would he like to develop what he has just said?

Gladly. What the hon. Gentleman said in justification for what his right hon. Friend the Minister is doing was that that was only what we on this side had done—and done more than once. In actual fact, that simply is not true. The National Health Service Contributions Act of 1957, which is the principal Act, and the legislation upon which this Clause is based, was introduced by his right hon. Friends. The first extension of that, the Act of 1958, was once again a Conservative Measure and here, for the third time, we have an extension once more.
What I was saying was that the Financial Secretary at least made some effort to get some real debating, some real clash of opinion. He reached some kind of conclusion, but there was not one supporter of the Clause on the other side of the Committee who really came out publicly avowing enthusiasm for this Bill.
We have been taken through a veritable maze of statistical lists and percentages and all the rest of it by the Financial Secretary and the farther we went through that maze, the farther we got away from the Clause which we are supposed to be discussing. This Clause simply provides for a higher rate of National Health Service contribution, and to my mind the only thing which we know, and the only opinion we have against which to judge that, has been a statement by the Minister of Health. It was that unless the Bill is passed we shall not get a development of the hospital services.
I hope that the Financial Secretary reads his speech tomorrow—or the day after. In the first part of it he said that in judging this Clause one had to consider the tax system as a whole; but about twenty minutes later, when my hon. Friend the Member for Fulham (Mr. M. Stewart)—I think it was my hon. Friend—took him up on some point of explanation of his statistical survey, he said he was not going to be drawn over the tax system as a whole. Our argument is that we have been given no opportunity to consider this in relation to the tax system as a whole.
He knows as well as I do that the Budget will come along in a few weeks and on that occasion the Committee will have the opportunity of considering the whole question of revenue and expenditure and the priorities which the Government are proposing. We shall then have a chance to consider the tax system as a whole, but all we are confronted with tonight is a specific task which really returns the Committee to one of the jobs of the Committee of Supply somewhere in the 17th century of providing specific ways of gathering money for specific purposes. We are applying ourselves to increased contributions in respect of the National Health Service.
I am disappointed because I have a certain respect for the honesty of the Financial Secretary. Just consider what he said in response to the speech of my hon. Friend the Member for Cannock (Miss Lee). "Here is a difference," he said, "here is a lack of unity. Someone has talked about a poll tax, but the hon. Lady says that it is not a poll tax. It does not fall on everyone, and so she objects." Where is the lack of unity there? Let the hon. Gentleman go back and look again at his own tax.
Of course it does not fall on everyone, and to that extent it may well be that it is unfair. It falls only upon people who hold a National Insurance card. For each one of them it is a poll tax; in whichever category they come, they pay the 10d., 8d. or 6d., irrespective of differences in income. But quite apart from those who hold National Insurance cards. there may well be people who are far better off but who do not hold such a card and who do not need to. They can, perhaps, elect not to need to do so.
I instanced the case of the 10s. widow who has to work on to get her pension. She will pay 8d. We read in the Evening Standard that the Daily Telegraph has done very well and made a profit of about £610,000. The directors, five of them I think, are to share £18,000.
Very proper.
And one of them is a widow, a titled widow—
Shocking.

The shocking thing is that if she holds a card, which is most unlikely, she will probably pay 6d., whereas the 10s. widow will pay 8d. a week. Is that fair? Is that just? Is that a proper way to finance the development of our hospital services?
She will be paying Surtax, and she will probably pay for her own doctor.

How do we know what will happen to Surtax when the Budget comes? When the Minister of Health in 1957 introduced the first National Health Service contribution, and when he doubled it, he said that it would relieve the general body of taxpayers of an equivalent amount. When the Budget came, the Surtax payers were relieved. That was not only discriminatory taxation in relation to a tax that falls generally on the employed classes, but it was equally discriminatory relief. If hon. and right hon. Members opposite can justify to themselves that this is the way to fulfil the task which, the Minister of Health said, depended upon the passing of the Bill, they disappoint me.
I have a feeling that right hon. and hon. Members opposite are rather
ashamed of the Clause. That is why we have had no speeches from them. That is why they want the thing done quickly, as if to say "Let us legislate and let us forget it." They want the result of it and what it will enable the Chancellor of the Exchequer to do in respect of his friends, but they are not proud of the fact that as part of this great new development the rich will pay 10d. and the poor will pay 10d. This is a new suggestion of equity from the guardians of British justice and the defenders of the poor.
One of the points on which we should like to have had a good discussion is the question of the appointed day. It may well be that we can persuade the representative of the Treasury, which has to appoint the day, that it should be sometime after the next election, when hon. Members opposite would have the opportunity of persuading directly their electors of the justice of this proposal. There was no mention of this kind of proposal at the last election. I have taken great trouble to go through various election broadcasts and leaflets. I have some election addresses with me which make wonderful reading. [Interruption.] "Fiction" certainly is the word. [Interruption.] Hon. Members opposite have something about which to blame themselves, certainly not something to be proud of. [Interruption.] I wish that the hon. Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro) would learn to resist the seductions of his own voice.
The most respectable origins of the Bill are in pessimism and panic, panic because hon. Members opposite discovered that the economy is not quite as sound as they proclaimed to the world and pessimism because they have no confidence in themselves to get started again the growth of the economy, whose buoyancy would wipe out the possibility of this problem and the need for any increased taxation of this kind.

The hon. Member is wrong. It was precisely because forecasts, in the Treasury as well as outside, suggested that there would be a quite substantial rise in production this year that it became more important, and not less important, to keep the net increase of Government expenditure within some sort of bounds.

This is still Government expenditure. What is the hon. Gentleman talking about? It only means that the expenditure is being paid for by money raised in a different way. The hon. Gentleman tried twice today to put over the idea that taxation is something that happens only during the Budget. He has not admitted that this is taxation, although, somehow or other, it is a different kind of taxation. There is no logic in this.
We on this side are very much concerned at this extension of something that we considered in 1957 and again in 1958 as unfair and unreasonable and as enshrining all the Tory prejudice concerning the financing of our social services.
3.30 a.m.
What is happening here is a shedding of the burden. I do not doubt that by gagging, the Closure and the use of the majority—their silent majority—the Government will be able to get the Bill through—
Silent?

—but my hon. Friends and I are determined that this shall not be a permanent feature of our social legislation. I hope that my hon. Friends will continue this debate still further to persuade the Government and to rub their noses into something of which they are pretty well thoroughly ashamed.
Mrs. Castle.
rose—
What about the Question being now put? Where is the Chief Whip? Send for him.

Sir Herbert, I do not intend at this hour of the morning to attempt to shout down the hon. Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro), and I ask for the protection of the Chairman against his iniquitous voice.
He is becoming a nuisance.
Becoming?
Perhaps all hon. Members will take note of the fact that debates can be more easily conducted if there is quietness in all quarters of the Committee.

Thank you, Sir Herbert.
We have had from the Financial Secretary to the Treasury some very interesting admissions. We have had it clearly established in the first place that what we are discussing is a tax. We have also had it frankly admitted that what we are discussing is a poll tax. We have even had it admitted that what we are discussing is a regressive tax.
I admire the honesty of the Financial Secretary in making this admission, because he went on to say that in the Conservative view an element of regressive taxation in our general taxation was a good thing. He pointed out, and claimed, that, despite this element of regressive taxation, the greatest proportion of our social services would continue to be financed out of general taxation.
