He gave us figures Which included all the social services, not only the Health Service and social insurance but education as well—which I thought was rather significant. I became a little uneasy when I heard the hon. Gentleman claiming it as a virtue that the Government are not yet financing our education system by means of a poll tax contribution. Perhaps that is the next item on the list.
This brings us to the very kernel of the matter, because what the Financial Secretary told us was that regressive taxation in itself is not in Conservative eyes a bad thing. He said that it is all a matter of degree. To us it is something else. It is a matter of direction. It is the direction of the Government's policy and not only its degree which alarms us. I do not care how many figures the Financial Secretary produces to show how great a proportion of our social services is still financed by what is surely the best and most traditional method of financing social services—progressive direct taxation. We want to know what the trend is—not the degree but the direction. What is this the beginning of and where will it end?
I should like to challenge the Financial Secretary with some figures of my own—if I can still understand them at this hour of the morning. Taking the ten-year period 1951–61, what trend do we find running through the taxation processes which have been pursued by successive Conservative Governments? We find that during these past ten years
national income has risen some 25 per cent. We find that during the same period the total yield for taxes on income and profits has risen by some 12 per cent., but the yield of National Insurance and National Health and Industrial Injuries contributions has gone up during this period not by 12 per cent. but by 90 per cent. We also find that the yield of National Health Service contributions alone has gone up during this period by 180 per cent.
It is, therefore, against the background of this trend that we have to consider this legislation tonight. We have to consider it all the more because of the different standards applied by this Government in measuring the capacity of of different classes of citizens in this country to pay contributions to the cost of the social services. This Government are now applying quite different criteria of capacity to pay to different sections of the community and to different types of citizen.
The Government have been arguing that National Health and National Insurance contributions should bear the same proportionate relationship to income in 1961 as they did in 1946. One of the biggest arguments the hon. Gentleman has put forward in favour of the increased insurance contribution payable under this Bill is that average earnings have increased; therefore, the tax should increase. Surely, if this argument is applicable in the case of contributions it should be applicable logically in the case of Income Tax, and if the hon. Gentleman is saying that the insurance contribution should bear the same proportionate relationship to income today as they did in 1946 what he is logically saying is, as Professor Titmuss pointed out in a letter to The Times the other day, that we ought to return to the rates of Income Tax and Surtax which obtained in 1946. That is the local deduction from his policy. Is that what the Government are going to propose in the Budget? I very much doubt it.
Instead of increases in Income Tax and Surtax we have this type of taxation. Progressive direct taxation has been reduced in no less than seven out of ten Budgets in the past ten years. [HON. MEMBERS: "Hear, hear."] Hon. Gentlemen opposite applaud, but they do not
realise how much they are giving themselves away by doing so. They are admitting that it is Conservative policy that progressive direct taxation should fall with the rise of income and that poll tax should rise with the rises. It has been our argument during the debates on this Bill that the purpose and deliberate philosophy of taxation of hon. Members opposite is steadily to widen the gap between rich and poor.
We have had the argument used about average earnings having risen, but average earnings do not tell us what is actually happening in society. Millions of workers do not get the average. It is no good coming along, as hon. Members opposite have during these debates, saying, "Look at the height of average earnings. Do you suppose this extra 10d. will hurt?". It is the very nature of an average that it does not represent the actual earnings of millions of people. There must be many people earning below the average. When the Financial Secretary said that this was a tax which was discriminatory in the right way because many people would not come within its scope, I wondered whether he had studied the Schedule. Has he looked at some of the people who automatically will have this additional impost imposed upon them without regard to the social justice of it?
Order. I hope that the hon. Lady will not anticipate the debate on the Schedule.

I shall have a great deal more to say on that subject when we reach the Schedule. I am merely using it as an illustration in answer to a point made by the Financial Secretary, who prayed in aid of his argument that this tax was discriminatory in the right way. It is just as pertinent that I should give an example of the type of person who will have to carry this burden.
Self-employed boys and girls under the age of 18 and non-employed boys and girls under the age of 18 at present pay 1s. 2d. and in future will pay Is. 6d. That is not a small increase, proportionately—and when we are considering this taxation we are considering questions of proportion. The Financial Secretary sees this purely in terms of statistics. I wish that he could visualise the sort of person who will have to pay
this increased charge. Has he studied any of the leaflets published by the Ministry of Pensions and National Insurance?
One of our difficulties in arguing this case with the Treasury Bench is that we are not arguing it with a man concerned with the social or medical problems of the Health Service. We are arguing it with a computer, that is all. We are arguing it with a political computer. The human being is only a digit so insignificant as not to count in this financial calculation. I suggest to the Financial Secretary that he would not have said that this tax is discriminatory in the right way if he had had even the slightest knowledge of the insurance categories of the people who will be affected.
Who are these non-employed and self-employed boys and girls under 18? To a large degree they are students who are continuing their full-time education or their apprenticeships. They are people who have struggled up from working-class homes to try to make a better place for themselves in the world. What do the insurance regulations say about them? If a boy is continuing his full-time education his contributions as a non-employed person are credited for certain periods, but if he wants to keep insured while on full-time education he may be faced with the alternative of paying the contribution or getting his parents to pay it or, on the other hand, having deficiencies in his insurance record when he begins full-time work.
3.45 a.m.
It is to people like these that these sums apply. Once and for all we must dispose of the Financial Secretary's argument that this kind of increased burden is tolerable because not only have average wages gone up but under this magnificent Conservative Government we have had such a vast expansion of the social services that the social reward has gone up and on every side the worker has reaped the benefits of the sacrifices of hon. Members opposite. We had a little bit of this kind of thing from the Chancellor of the Exchequer on Second Reading.
Where is he?

The right hon. Gentleman denied the accusation that the Government were chipping away and try-
ing to dismantle the welfare services. The argument used for altering the basis of the financing of the Health Service has been that other services are expanding so much and costing so much more that the extra burden of the hospital development programme is the final straw that is breaking the Surtax camel's back.
The Chancellor said that the answer to the accusation lay …in the facts and figures. This year the combined Votes for which my right hon. Friends the Ministers of Housing and Local Government, Education, Pensions and National Insurance, and Health are expected to total over £2,025 million. In 1951–52 similar Vote expenditure totalled £1,100 million. We are continuing that policy. For the current year we estimate that we shall spend £140 million more than last year. Next year we estimate that we shall spend a further £100 million."—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 15th February, 1961; Vol. 634, c. 1645.] Hon. Members opposite quote this as a sign of the tremendous expansion of the social services, but the answer to that argument was given only two or three days ago in no less an authoritative journal than The Times which in its leader column, discussing the new Civil Estimates which had been presented and the increase of between £200 million and £300 million in them compared with the previous year's original estimates said: …these increases in large measure reflect not so much failure to control real expenditure as failure to control the value of the currency. The Government, therefore, through their economic policy, have confronted us with a steady depreciation of the pound so that the nominal figures for increases in social service expenditure do not represent any real increases in the social services. They then present this Bill and tell the Committee that to enable them to keep pace with their own inflationary policies they must redistribute the financial burden of the social services on to the shoulders of the very people who are feeling the burden of inflation. It is for this reason that we on this side of the Committee continue to challenge the Government. They are introducing a measure of increasingly regressive taxation now as a permanent part of Conservative philosophy. We warn the people that. if they allow this to go through unchallenged, if they accept this because it is "only a little one," they will find that they have not only an illegitimate baby on
their hands, but a whole progeny of illegal and illegitimate taxation.

Despite the temptation of the hour, I do not propose to make a long speech—[HON. MEMBERS: "Go on."] I propose to submit to the Committee a reason against the higher rate of contributions which I have not yet heard expressed and which had not occurred to me until it was put forward by a constituent.
I have had more letters about this Bill than about any subject since the Suez crisis. I would be out of order to quote many of those letters because they refer not to the increased contributions but to the increased charges. They are from the aged, the widowed and the chronically sick.
How many letters has the hon. Member had?
How many has he had about the bomb?
It is impossible for me to say how many, but within the first three days of the publication of the Bill I received 39, which is an extraordinary number when a Bill of this kind is introduced.
Will hon. Members opposite offer to pay the postage which we have had to pay in answering these letters?
The debate is becoming triangular.

One letter came from a young man who complained about the increase in the contributions for a reason new to me. He said that he would complain against the increase in any case, but the real ground of his objection was that while he might have been prepared to accept it if he had been asked to pay more for a better Health Service, he would not accept it when the poorest, those who were most sick and those who needed help most were to get the least help.
He pointed out one fact which should be in our minds in considering this increased contribution. It was announced simultaneously with another burden which those who are poorest have to bear.
There had been a promise of increased pensions and benefits in April. In the same week that the terms of this Bill were announced forms were sent out from the National Assistance Board to say that the increases these people were to receive in pensions and benefits would be wiped out by deductions in National Assistance.
So, in one week, came those two blows to the poorest, the weakest, those whose lot is hardest in the community. My friend, protesting against this increased contribution, wrote that one of the reasons for his bitterness at being asked to pay this increased contribution was that those who had already been disappointed over their increased pensions and benefits were to suffer again under this Bill, that they were to pay more for their prescriptions. He will pay, but he and we would feel much better if the rich in the land gave their proper proportion towards the cost, instead of imposing upon the poorest the same charge that they are shirking.
I have already indicated the double burden imposed by the deductions from National Assistance benefits and increased charges and contributions. The second ground on which my correspondent objected to this increased contribution lay in examples of his own relatives. He has chronically ill relatives, required week by week to get prescriptions, many of which contain a number of items. He feels that his increased contribution will not benefit them because they are in a worse position following the increased prescription charges.
I want to point out to the right hon. Gentleman the Secretary of State for Finance—
I have been called "right hon. Gentleman" almost throughout these debates. I am not a right hon. Gentleman—still less am I a Secretary of State.

There is more virtue in overstatement than in understatement in congratulations. My criticism applies whether he is a right hon. or an hon. Gentleman. It is not good enough for him to hide behind a conjuring trick of terminology on the question whether this is discriminatory or regressive. In our view discrimination occurs when those who are poorest have to pay a higher
proportion of their income than those who are richer. He cannot deny that that is happening under the Bill. I hope that these considerations will be in our minds when we are opposing the Clause, and I ask the Committee to reject it.

tr.td: Butter, Rt. Hn. R. A. (Saffron Walden)

speech.p: rose in his place, and claimed to move, That the Question be now put.
Question put, That the Question be now put:—
The Committee divided: Ayes 219, Noes 176.

tr.td: Mr. E. Wakefield and Mr. Finlay.
Gordon Walker, Rt, Hon. P. C
Mr. Cronin and Mr. I. Davies.

speech.p: Question put accordingly, That the Clause stand part of the Bill:—

tr.td: Butler, Rt. Hn. R. A. (Saffron Walden)

speech.p: The Committee divided:Ayes 221, Noes 175.

tr.td: Gordon Walker, Rt. Hon. P. C.
Wilcock, Group Capt. C. A. B.
Mr. Cronin and Mr. I. Davies

speech.speakername: The Secretary of State for the Home Department (Mr. R. A. Butler)
speech.p:
I beg to move, That the Chairman do report Progress and ask leave to sit again. We have obtained Clause 1. When the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Belper (Mr. G. Brown) interrogated my right hon. and learned Friend the Chancellor of the Exchequer, my right hon. and learned Friend replied that we would review the situation later when we knew about Clause 1. Clause 1 is now obtained, and that we regard as the most likely progress we are able to make tonight. I would point out to the Committee that, if we proceed to a later hour, we shall not be likely in the circumstances through which we have passed to make very much more progress than we have made. Clause 1 is the major Clause of the Bill. It has been carefully traversed, and we have debated it for approximately twelve hours. It is interesting to note that the previous Bill in 1958 passed through the whole of its Committee stage in eight hours. On this occasion, one major Clause has taken twelve hours.
We are satisfied that we have obtained the Clause. As Leader of the House, I have also to think that the House was up very late last night. I have to think not only of hon. Members but also of the staff and other arrangements. In the circumstances, Sir Gordon, I think this is the right time to report Progress and ask leave to sit again.

My right hon. and hon. Friends are perfectly willing to carry on. [HON. MEMBERS: "Hear, hear."] It is true that it is difficult for us to improve this miserable, mean little Bill. Nevertheless, we have several pages of Amendments to the Schedule, and I know that my hon. Friends would be just as willing and assiduous in moving them and pressing them on the Government as they have been in their speeches on Clause 1.
I can understand the Government's concern. Their majority is dwindling. [HON. MEMBERS: "Oh."] It will have been observed by my hon. Friends that their majority was smaller for the first of the last two Divisions than for the second, which means that some hon. Members opposite were so sleepy that they could not get up for the first one.
Of course, that is clearly the explanation of the remark of the Leader of the House that this was the utmost they could get with the Bill tonight. In the circumstances, and having regard to the fact that the Government and their supporters are thoroughly exhausted and they have, in fact, surrendered as far as tonight is concerned, we are prepared to accept the Motion, but on the understanding, or with the reservation, to use the words generally adopted by the Leader of the House, that we intend to fight every line that we can of the Schedule when we return to it.

Not for the first time, I find myself in disagreement with the spokesmen from both Front Benches. Because the Government are defeatist and want to run away, I do not see any reason why my right hon. Friend and we on this side should allow them to run away or why we should run away ourselves. I have one personal objection to accepting the Motion at this moment. It looks to me very like a conspiracy between the two Front Benches to prevent me from having any say in the Bill.
I have sat here very nearly the whole of the time since the debate started. At the very moment when, from the look in your eye, Sir Gordon, I was quite sure that you were about to call me next in the debate, the Patronage Secretary—I hope not by design, but the coincidences have been so many that I suspect there must have been some plan behind it—got up and moved the Closure. [Interruption.] At least, he had it done. I quite understand that after the events of last week he is a little diffident about doing it himself, but he knows how to get it done and he got it done on each such occasion.
I am not entitled to criticise you, Sir Gordon, for accepting the Closure Motion—of course not—and I do not blame the Patronage Secretary for moving it in the circumstances.
He will move it again.

He knows exactly which speeches he wishes to avoid. When we reach a certain stage in the debate, he is anxious to avoid any more speeches at all, and at half-past four in the morning the Government begin to
have a compassionate interest in the welfare of the staff. It is a belated compassion. If they had acted in this way when my right hon. Friend moved a corresponding Motion at 11.30 p.m. yesterday, they might, perhaps, have expected us to believe in their sincerity when they come along at half-past four in the morning and say, "Of course, we are all right. We would go on for ever, only there is the staff to consider."

May I draw my hon. Friend's attention to an important aspect? The staff are now brought into the picture with an element of compassion from the Government benches, but if the staff fall sick and are ill as a result of the hardships that we have inflicted upon them they will still have to pay 2s. for each prescription item when they are ill.

I can always rely on my hon. Friend, when he intervenes in the speeches of his hon. Friends, to intervene helpfully, as he has done again on this occasion.
This is the acid test. If the Government have any compassion, they do not need to limit it to the staff. The staff have their place in the compassion of all of us, and as they have to live with us most of their lives perhaps we might remember them a little earlier than we have done this morning. If there were any real compassion behind it, we would have heard of it earlier and the Bill would never have been introduced.
I do not want to be uncharitable. It may be that the Leader of the House and the Chancellor of the Exchequer really had this sense of compassion for the staff hours ago. They are only mentioning it now, at half-past four in the morning, not because they did not think of it at a more timely hour, but because they have been fast asleep ever since and this is the first opportunity they have had to do so.
We have seen nothing of the Leader of the House all night. We had experiences last week. How dare he take the risk that the experiences of last week might not have been repeated tonight?
There has been a great deal of temptation and a great deal of provocation. Perhaps the right hon. Gentleman, as so frequently with him, is full of valour as well as compassion, but his discretion
amounts to more than the two other qualities combined and so he keeps out of the way.
4.30 a.m.
We say a little more of the Chancellor of the Exchequer. He was here at 11.30 p.m. I do not know where he has been since. He told us at 11.30 that in a couple of hours' time he would be prepared to review the position. The couple of hours have spread to five hours. Now the right hon. Gentleman comes along prepared to review the situation. How in the world can he review a situation when he has been absent and asleep in the meantime? Do the Government say that they cannot get any further? Why should they not get Clause 2?
They do not want it.

But why should they not want it? They come along and say "We are so anxious for the Bill that we have sat up hour after hour because it was so important that we should get it. Then when we reach the stage when we are likely to get it, they have second thoughts and move, "That the Chairman do report Progress and ask leave to sit again!" If in the end, being a disciplined and co-operative member of my party, always loyal to its decisions, I comply against my better judgment with the advice tendered to the Committee by my right hon. Friend the Leader of the Opposition just now, it will only be because it gives the Government a breathing space for which they asked.
I can only read into the Government's request not the irrelevant compassion which they thought of so late but the fact that they are getting cold feet as a result of the arguments which have been pressed upon them. They are not nearly so satisfied that to everybody outside the justice and equity which they pretend to believe in in the Bill will be so apparent. They are beginning to have cold feet about it, and, that being so, perhaps they will have second thoughts about it.
It may be that if we agree with them now, the Government will come back to us tomorrow or next week and say, "We have changed our mind. If we are to have taxation for this purpose, we will have progressive instead of regressive taxation. We will alter the method of raising the money in a revolutionary way for a Tory Government. We
will alter it in such a way that the burdens will fall on the shoulders most able to bear them instead of on the shoulders least able to bear them."
In the hope that out of discretion, if not out of any sense of justice, the Government will reconsider the matter and withdraw the Bill altogether, I am prepared not to persist in my objection to the Motion.

p.i: Committee report Progress; to sit again upon Monday next.

publicwhip.major-heading: Orders of the Day — LAND, NEWCASTLE (USE)

speech.p: Motion made, and Question proposed, That this House do now adjourn. —[Mr. Finlay.]

I bring to the attention of the House the case of Mr. Bullock, a constituent of mine, because it is bound up with the larger issue of the proposed wastage of land by Newcastle City Council. I should like to outline the case of Mr. Bullock because I think it shows that with a little more thought and a little less obstinacy by the city council land which could be used for other purposes such as children's playgrounds or places for the recreation of the elderly is likely to be misused.
Some time ago Mr. Bullock wrote to Newcastle Town Hall submitting a plan to erect a garage in the garden of his house. Mr. Bullock is a council house tenant. After submitting his plan to the town hall, Mr. Bullock was given a tracing of the area in which he lived and was told to have it enlarged two and a half times, which would allow him to show clearly the exact position of the proposed garage. This Mr. Bullock did, and on 25th November, 1959, he received an official document stating that the plans deposited by him to erect a semi-permanent type of garage had been permitted under the building byelaws. Mr. Bullock unfortunately took this to mean that he could go ahead and erect his garage. He felt that if there were any snags then the town hall would inform him accordingly.
His view was strengthened by an article which appeared in the Evening Chronicle and which was written by the then municipal correspondent, which stated categorically that car owning council house tenants in Newcastle would be allowed to build their own garages. To emphasise the point more, the article then quoted Councillor J. Burton, the Chairman of Newcastle's Housing Management Committee, as follows: We want to get rid of the untidiness of some estates where cars are left parked in the streets overnight or on any piece of open land. This new freedom to tenants will not solve the problem but will make a very useful contribution towards a solution. More important still, it gives people a chance to do something for themselves. Therefore, hon. Members can imagine the shock Mr. Bullock had when he received a letter from the Housing Management Committee telling him that as he had not bad permission from that department to erect the garage he must remove the structure forthwith.
Naturally, Mr. Bullock was upset about this and contacted the Chairman of Newcastle Housing Management Committee. I have here the actual letter from the Chairman to Mr. Bullock, and I should like to quote one section of it: The Housing Manager informs we that what you did get was planning permission to erect a garage as shown on the plans submitted by you to the City Engineer, and they, and the Planning Committee, assumed that you had obtained the necessary permission from your landlord, which is the Housing Management Committee". In passing, may I say what a sad reflection it is that there is so little co-ordination between two committees of the same council, and that by this my constituent, Mr. Bullock, has suffered a great deal of inconvenience and worry.
The snag in respect of the Housing Management Committee is that the council as landlords of council houses in the City do not as a matter of policy permit garages where the tenant does not have rear access. This, I think, is an iniquitous restriction. I served for eight years on a local authority, and the ruling there was that council tenants who wanted to erect a garage in their garden could do so provided that they had sufficient space and easy access and that the proposed garage was of a satisfactory standard.
I can see the point of Newcastle City Council endeavouring to keep their council estates attractive and not allowing any ramshackle buildings in the gardens, but surely the Planning Committee could ensure that no unsuitable garages were built. By their policy of allowing only those council house tenants who have rear access to build garages, I believe that Newcastle's Housing Management Committee are not only guilty of making things more difficult for their tenants but are also guilty of wasting land—and I will return to that point in a minute, because I believe that this is something for which there is Ministerial responsibility.
Since it was announced in the local papers that I intended to raise this matter on the Adjournment, Councillor Dan Smith, who is the Chairman of both the Planning and Housing Committees in Newcastle, has made a statement in the Evening Chronicle of Monday, 6th February, which reads as follows: As with a tenant in a private house, if he wants to build a garage he should apply to the owner". He said that the council was soon starting work on 700 garages for its tenants on special sites, adding, We feel that allowing garages to be built in gardens restricts the re-letting to a car owner and that is surely wrong". That is a piece of nonsense, because if other local authorities can allow their tenants to build garages in their gardens without demanding rear access and do not have trouble with reletting these houses, why should Newcastle have trouble? In any case, Councillor Smith's statement is entirely without logic, because as the City Council allow some tenants with rear access to build their own garages, there must he some council houses in Newcastle which have garages attached to them, and I have never heard of any problem of these houses being difficult to re-let.
To sum up, in any urban area such as Newcastle where building land is so very difficult to obtain. I think that it is scandalous that the City Council should be planning to use land to build garages for council house tenants, many of whom have the necessary space and easy access and are only too anxious to build their own garages in their gardens. If my hon. Friend's Ministry, therefore, can make
Newcastle City Council see sense on this matter, I believe that some of the land which it is now proposed should be used for these garages could be used for other purposes, and many council house tenants would be extremely grateful for being given the opportunity of having the convenience of a garage at their home.

speech.speakername: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Housing and Local Government (Sir Keith Joseph)
speech.p:
My hon. Friend the Member for Newcastle-upon-Tyne, East (Mr. Montgomery), who is always assiduous in the attention which he gives to his constituents, has raised the case of Mr. Bullock, and no one who heard his description of what happened could withhold his sympathy from Mr. Bullock for the frustration and irritation which must have been caused him. I must straight away confess to my hon. Friend, however, that my right hon. Friend has no power whatever to intervene in what is essentially an estate management affair of a local authority. This is quite outside the scope of the powers or discretion given by Parliament to my right hon. Friend. Of course my right hon. Friend can discuss this sort of thing with a local authority, but probably any need to do that any further will have been saved by the discussion that my hon. Friend has launched today.
My hon. Friend therefore will not expect from me much detailed comment on what he has said, but I should like to refer briefly to several complaints or allegations that he has made about Newcastle Council. First, he commented on the Council's way of conducting its affairs with particular reference to the fact that Mr. Bullock was given the green light—if I may use the phrase—by I think the fourth department of the Council, only to find a very firm red light shone by the fifth department.
As my hon. Friend will realise, the fifth department, the Housing Management Committee, was exercising its powers as landlord, while the other four departments responsible for granting him planning permission, for by-law approval, for seeing that the garage concerned was rated, and for arranging for the run-in to the garage to be built at Mr. Bullock's
expense, were all operating as local authority departments rather than as owners or landlords.
Nevertheless one cannot but agree with my hon. Friend in thinking that, at least at first sight of the evidence, one would gather from what has happened that one department is not quite in the picture about what another department is doing. One knows very little more about this case than my hon. Friend has said and there may be some good reason not known to him or me why it is that the four departments of a local authority should assume that a particular process may go ahead while it should have been apparent to them according to the normal rules and regulations that the fifth department would not allow that development.
There is the criticism that a housing authority's housing management committee should forbid any private garage being built by a council tenant at his own expense on the site of his council house unless that garage has access to the rear, which of course would require a back road of some sort to serve that access. No other council I know of applies this rule but that is no reason why Newcastle should not stick to its regulation if it wishes.
It is true, as far as I can see, that this regulation makes it practically impossible on an existing council estate, where there are no back lanes or other means of rear service, for council tenants to have a garage of their own. In that case it must lead, in what I hope will be more and more a car-owning democracy, to extensive street parking. This is all the more so where there are no longer any odd bits of land for groups of garages to be built. But this is entirely within the council's discretion and my right hon. Friend has no power to intervene even if he wished to do so, and there may be a good reason for the Newcastle regulation. I hope that as a result of this debate those concerned may look at their regulations again but that is as far as I can go.
My hon. Friend thinks that here there is possibly some waste of housing land and as my right hon. Friend is known to be anxious to increase the amount of land available for housing he might be able to intervene on that count. But I must point out that we are here dealing with an existing estate and Mr. Bullock is
not concerned with a new plot on a new housing estate where there might be some case for discussing whether the lay-out provided, if it were to provide for garages which had to be served by a rear access, was wasteful. But that is not the position which we are discussing. We are discussing existing housing estates where there is no room for groups of garages and where the housing plots may well have been rather larger in the past than they are now. There may well be sites by each house, or by many houses, for a garage and for a garage to be built if the tenant so wished and could get permission if there were not this regulation about rear access.
But we are not here in a position to discuss Newcastle's arrangements in its new housing estates. I understand that the Newcastle authorities propose with their new housing sites to build groups of garages and those groups of garages may be on land which is not suitable
for housing. If my hon. Friend says that a group of garages will waste more housing land than if tenants were allowed to build their own private garages within their own curtilage, I must point out that perhaps the curtilages on new housing estates will not be as lavish as with the old housing estates and there might therefore not be room for building garages, but that is not under discussion, because in his case it is an existing housing estate which is being discussed.
My right hon. Friend is naturally sorry for Mr. Bullock, but this is entirely a local authority affair and all I can say is to hope that the local authority will look again at its arrangements. More than that, my right hon. Friend cannot do in this case.

p.i: Adjourned accordingly at eight minutes to Five o'clock a.m.
